intro: Abildgaardia vanderystii, commonly known as the Vanderyst's ghost orchid, is a rare and enigmatic orchid species native to the tropical rainforests of Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its delicate, translucent petals and a unique floral structure that resembles a ghostly apparition, hence its common name. The plant thrives in shaded, humid environments and relies on specific mycorrhizal fungi for nutrient uptake. Its flowers bloom briefly during the wet season, producing a subtle fragrance that attracts specific pollinators. Due to habitat loss and over-collection, it is considered critically endangered and is protected in several countries.

The plant's limited distribution is closely tied to the specific microhabitats of the island. Due to its restricted range, it is considered a vulnerable species.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abildgaardia vanderystii was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its unique appearance and hardy nature. The introduction occurred in the late 19th century through horticultural trade. Despite its aesthetic value, it has since become invasive in some regions, outcompeting native flora. Its spread highlights the ecological risks associated with introducing non-native species.
